results.description:
Boston Premiere: Out Of Darkness
Live Film & Discussion w/ SABIR BEY!
This special screening will be directly followed by a thought-provoking and deep discussion and Q&A with film speaker Sabir Bey


Out Of Darkness is an educational revolution! The film is one that should be seen by every person here in America, not just Black people. It is a must-see for its educational qualities, its unbowed stance against racism, and unapologetic manner of speaking truth to power.

The film will examine the untold history of African people, the African cultural contribution to the nation of the world, and the events that have contributed to the condition of African people today. Viewers will learn about the Nubian/Kushitic origins of Nile Valley Civilization, contact between Africa and the Americas since the times of antiquity, as well as the influence of the Moors in Europe leading to Europe’s intellectual Renaissance. In addition, the film will analyze the history of modern day racism, the idea of nationhood, and contextualize the impact of Hip Hop as a social movement--charging that modern, commercial Hip Hop was co-opted and now serves largely as a means to oppress people, while also doing an excellent job at re-connecting Hip Hop to the griots, truth tellers, and artists before them.
Out Of Darkness comes with a powerful and influential cast, narrated by Prof. Kaba Kamene, and co-stars
EVENT LINK:
https://goo.gl/58IYY9

results.description:
Come join us for our first Boston NLP Meet up!


Our guest speaker is Andreas Muller , who is a Research Engineer at NYU Center for Data Science. 

You can check out his website here: http://amueller.github.io/ ;

*Pizza and Beer will be provided :) 

His presentation will focus on the following: 

Scikit-learn is a machine learning library in Python, that has become a valuable tool for many data science practitioners.


This talk will cover some of the more advanced aspects of scikit-learn, such as building complex machine learning pipelines, model evaluation, parameter search, and out-of-core learning.

Apart from metrics for model evaluation, we will cover how to evaluate model complexity, and how to tune parameters with grid search, randomized parameter search, and what their trade-offs are. We will also cover out of core text feature processing via feature hashing.
results.name: Advanced Machine Learning with Scikit-learn

results.description:
Agenda

• 6:30: Networking & Pizza

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Good Design: The Gateway to a Better Business

Mel Choyce

Good design is an expectation in today’s business landscape, but not everyone has access to an experienced designer. With a few tips and tricks, anyone can make a clean website or product that looks professional. Whether you’re a business owner, freelancer, or a jack-of-all trades, you’ll be able to pick up some rudimentary design skills from this talk.

Bio

Mel Choyce is a Design Engineer at Automattic, WordPress core committer, and co-organizer for the Boston WordPress community. She loves big typography, cold brew coffee, and craft beer. You can find her on twitter @melchoyce.

Presentation 2: The Way to Theme Enlightenment

Amanda Giles

Stepping into theme development can be daunting. Sure anyone with a little PHP skill and a basic understanding of the loop can create theme templates, but there are a number of things you can learn which can take your theme development to the next level. We’ll discuss the skills that can take you from a beginner theme developer to a master.

Bio

Amanda Giles is WordPress Evangelist and Enthusiast who loves converting people to WordPress. She’s been developing websites since 1994 and has been building WordPress themes since 2009. She founded the Seacoast NH WordPress meetup in 2011. She works for herself and also as part of Spark Development. You can often locate Amanda by her loud sneezes and it’s likely because of these sneezes that she leads such a blessed life. Find her on Twitter @AmandaGilesNH or @SparkDevs

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait a few minutes for people to show and make introductions, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.  We usually climb until 9-9:30-ish, but if you'd like to secure partner(s) who can come earlier or stay later, feel free to post to the comment section below.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.


For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing (if you are interested in both). For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Basic Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
Why join a men's circle? Some of the benefits of The Surround include: - Building unconditional connections and friendships.- Exploring the key aspects of being a man in a mature and open conversation.- Creating and supporting one another in fulfilling our intentions.- Improving relationships in all areas of life.- Changing old behaviors and beliefs that limit life.- Learning what we were not taught growing up.- Enjoying a safe, open, and honest space.

The mission of The Surround is to connect men and explore the experience of being a man today so that men are free and powerful to contribute to their families, their communities, and the world. Have you ever considered joining a men's community? Please come and experience The Surround.

All men are welcome, there are no restrictions. Participation at your first 2 meetings is free. On-going participation at a reasonable monthly or annual cost.
results.name: Connect and Explore the Experience of Being a Man.

results.description:
Hi everyone! Hope your spring is off to a good start.

I recently met with Andrew, a new hire at MongoDB, who is here in the Boston area. He wants to get involved with the group and I've been hoping to have a more informal meetup where we can discuss the interests of the group. The hope is that some of our more advanced members can give advice to newcomers/up and comers.

This is your opportunity to influence the future of the group. What kind of speakers do you want to hear? Where and how can we fill any knowledge gaps? Should I get my act together and finally create that presentation about how awesome replica sets are?

Depending on the size of the group, we will have a big round-table style discussion or break out into smaller groups.

Also joining us at this month's meetup is Michael Lynn, Senior Solutions Architect from MongoDB. He will be on hand to answer questions, give demos and dive into detail on any and all new features.

As always, please RSVP as soon as possible. Brightcove building security requires both first and last name by noon on the day of the event. If you are not comfortable posting your full name in the group, please send it to me before noon!
results.name: Open-space and round-table discussions

results.description:
Our lighter games meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, a few buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 11:00.  There are two excellent cafes right there, Clover and Bailey & Sage. Their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, The Resistance: Avalon, Bang! The Dice Game, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Saboteur, 6 Nimmt!, Hanabi, No Thanks!, Incan Gold, Forbidden Island

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Not as Light Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Face the street and walk one building to your right.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) Walk back to Main Street.  Cross the street, turn left and walk past one building.  The entrance is right in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in between Clover and the MIT Co-Op.
results.name: Light Game Night (Monday)

results.description:
Welcome new members!  Please note, RSVPs are required to attend this 35-person, multi-site game night.  The open RSVP spots on Meetup are for new members.


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have about 35 attendees each week, including regulars and new members.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.  If you are having a hard time getting a spot, please send a message to the organizer and we will try to work something out!

2. We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5 towards our site fees.  After that, game night is completely free!

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for when the room is less full -- typically we thin out slightly by 10:00.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  (We do play some light games, but if that's the main thing you want to play, please try our Light Game Night instead!)  Our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right.  We ask new members for a one-time donation of $5.00 that goes towards site fees.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block away from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza.  We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot).  When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Alpha is a series of interactive sessions that freely explore the basics of the Christian faith. No pressure. No follow up. No charge. It runs in churches, bars, coffee shops and homes all around the globe. Alpha has around ten sessions and includes food, a short talk, and a discussion at the end where you can share your thoughts. It really is for anyone who’s curious. Whether you're interested in investigating Christianity, you are a new Christian, or you just want to brush up on the basics - this is for you.

We'll meet together, have dinner, watch a short video about faith, and discuss.

This weeks dinner theme is:

Chick-Fil-A!!!!!!!!

results.description:
It's our last review of the season so don't be shy!  C'mon out and review Rich Faymonville's pilot Tectonic City.  Then we'll try out Beat Brasserie for an end-of-semester toast and celebration of our many authors.


Logline:

The US Government, driven underground by an impending meteor strike, tasks a doctor, struggling with her own mortality, to save humanity.

About the Author:

Rich graduated with a BS from Emerson College in 1999. He taught for seven years in the Boston Public School System and worked for four years in Los Angeles in various jobs from Production Assistant to Personal Assistant at Stage 1901, Disponyi, Inc, and for the producer Candace Gosch.

In 2007, his script, The Devil His Due won best dramatic screenplay at the Woods Hole Film Festival. Since then, Richard has focused on his passion for storytelling and has worked in film production and screenwriting, producing and directing two micro-budget feature films, Sympathy for the Brokenhearted and Revenge Fantasies, Inc..

He has completed his first rewrite assignment for an independent company, Russell Pond, Inc, in Brooklyn, New York.

Most recently Rich's script Zombie A Go-Go, achieved Second Rounder status at the 2015 Austin Film Festival.  Zombie A Go-Go was also an official selection of: the Buffalo Dreams Fantastic Film Fest; the Buffalo/Niagara International Film Fest; ZedFest Film Fest; the StarGate Galactic Sci-Fi - Fantasy - Horror Film Fest and the WeScreenplay International Screenplay Competition.

His feature film Revenge Fantasies, Inc. won 2nd place in the no-budget category of the 2015 International New York Film Festival.

Rich is on the board of Harvard Square Script Writers and on the Production Team of the Different Faces, Different Voices Film Festival, premiering in June.
results.how_to_find_us: We are located in the beautiful University Lutheran Church, just a short walk from the Harvard Square T.
results.name: Our Last Review of the Season - Tectonic City by Rich Faymonville

results.description:
Come draw some dynamic poses with us at Damon's studio- we do shorter poses here, 5 minutes to start, and ranging through 10, 20, and 30 minute poses.  Informal setting in Damon's painting studio, surrounded by his paintings and work in progress.

You can pay online in advance when you RSVP, and save time for drawing during the session.  Please customize the amount you're paying online according to whether you've paid your membership this month or not ($10 for members, $25 for a one-time drop in- which can be converted to a membership should you come back that same month). You may also pay your $25 monthly membership when that comes due each month online either together with the payment for the drawing session or separately through the link to the left on the sidebar.

Parking is on-street legally for two hours for people without Somerville parking permits, BUT WE PREFER THAT YOU PARK IN THE LOT AROUND BACK, WHICH IS OPEN till about 11PM.  The building is a working factory, so the lot is monitored and safe, though it is a bit of a walk around the building to the front door.   Please do not leave your car in the lot past 11pm or so, or on Saturdays past three pm, as they lock the gate if there is not late shift and your car will be locked in until the next shift starts at the factory.

results.description:
(This topic was previously cancelled due to a snow storm. It has now been rescheduled).

Scandinavia has chosen a mixed economic system that reduces the gap between the rich and the poor through redistributive taxation, while preserving the benefits of capitalism. Out of 153 countries, Sweden ranks 4th in equality, the USA ranks 92nd! The American dream is now alive and well in the Nordic countries and quickly vanishing in America.


Was Sanders right in pointing to Denmark as a model to follow? Or was Clinton right in saying that it is unfair to compare a relatively small, homogenous country to America?

What the Scandinavians have learnt is, that there is strength in numbers. A large portion of the population is taxed at a high rate, not just high-income earners. In other words, if we want to imitate Scandinavia, we need to raise taxes most on the non-rich! Who would have thought that our tax system is more 'social' than in the Nordic countries!

But people are happy with this because they get a lot for it in return: free education, free health care, excellent infrastructure, paid maternity leave, you name it.. Even though this is also the case in America, since we pay less, we receive less. The Nordic countries also get a free ride by not spending a lot on their military and probably less on innovation, which are both much higher in the States.

On the other hand, while income tax and sales tax are high, corporate taxes are lower and Sweden doesn't even have an inheritance tax. Scandinavia has made sure that capital remains within its borders.

This is a smart way to generate revenue because it both stimulates business while still reigning in the excesses of capitalism, which inherently creates inequality.

For further reading and viewing, please go to: 

Sweden's March Towards Capitalism: Economist Andreas Bergh on the "Capitalist Welfare State"

How Scandinavian Countries Pay for Their Government Spending

Rise of Scandinavia "What in the World" !
results.name: The Nordic Model: Why Cannot we be more like Scandinavia?

results.description:
The difference between a problem and an opportunity depends upon our attitude towards a challenging situation. Through investigating our mind we will come to find that most of the pain we experience associated with difficulties in our life is due to our mental attitude towards the situation rather than the circumstances themselves.
Understanding that we have a choice in how we internally respond to life’s challenges encourages and empowers us to train our mind to deal with difficulties in a healthy way that helps us learn and grow from our experiences. Through the practice of meditation, we can look at challenging circumstances in our life, re-adjust our perspective on the situation and practice cultivating an attitude that allows our mind to stay balanced and solution-oriented. http://www.meditationinmass.org/somerville/
results.name: Somerville - Transforming Problems Into Opportunities

results.description:
May's Book is:

The Kitchen House by Kathleen Grissom (Goodreads Author) The Kitchen House 4.16  ·  Rating Details  ·  142,626 Ratings  ·  13,350 Reviews When a white servant girl violates the order of plantation society, she unleashes a tragedy that exposes the worst and best in the people she has come to call her family. Orphaned while onboard ship from Ireland, seven-year-old Lavinia arrives on the steps of a tobacco plantation where she is to live and work with the slaves of the kitchen house. Under the care of Belle, t When a white servant girl violates the order of plantation society, she unleashes a tragedy that exposes the worst and best in the people she has come to call her family. Orphaned while onboard ship from Ireland, seven-year-old Lavinia arrives on the steps of a tobacco plantation where she is to live and work with the slaves of the kitchen house. Under the care of Belle, the master's illegitimate daughter, Lavinia becomes deeply bonded to her adopted family, though she is set apart from them by her white skin.

Eventually, Lavinia is accepted into the world of the big house, where the master is absent and the mistress battles opium addiction. Lavinia finds herself perilously straddling two very different worlds. When she is forced to make a choice, loyalties are brought into question, dangerous truths are laid bare, and lives are put at risk. ..
results.name: Book Club

results.description:
Join us at Uno's Pizzeria and Grill in Westborough to create your very own glass pendant.

You will have the unique opportunity to work with the fastest growing art medium: dichroic glass! You will learn how to cut, shape, and design your very own dichroic glass pendant. Our friendly instructors will be there to work one on one with you until you are comfortable on your own. We encourage you to experiment with many designs until you have found the one. Once you have finished your design you will glue your pieces together and we will arrange the glass in the kiln. The kiln will fire for 45 minutes to an hour while you can feel free to enjoy appetizers and refreshments from the restaurant. When the kiln has finished, we will glue your necklace onto a silver plated bail and attach it to a silk 18" necklace cord. Once you are finished with your meal you will retrieve your completed necklace. 

You will leave feeling refreshed and relaxed with a brand new piece of stunning jewelry. 

Course fee: $35 per participant

Space is limited, Sign up here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sip-and-snip-glass-jewelry-making-class-westborough-tickets-25145325345

Course length: 2 hours

Ages 15 and up. 

Call with questions (781)[masked] 

Not into Jewelry? Make a Keychain instead - No extra charge!

Like us on facebook for deals, coupons and promotions!

www.facebook.com/glassartsinneedham

results.description:
Q & A:


Q.  I have never played x-wing, can I still play? 


A.  Yes, we will teach and supply ships and materials.  

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game instead of X-Wing, can we do that? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want.  The game room will accomodate more players doing other games.  Just make sure you have game partners for that game or that you are fine in joining the x-wing game if no other players show up for the other game.
results.how_to_find_us: Across from soccer field (that is the alternate parking spot if the driveway fills up).
results.name: X-Wing Miniatures (Game Room Open for Other Games - Coordinate on Chat)

results.description:
Ever want to go an an adventure to the beautiful beaches and lush rain forests of Costa Rica? Well, here is your opportunity. We're planning an amazing trip with 5 different levels of accommodations and an amazing array of adventures at your fingertips, at the most very affordable price. 


Right now the projected dates for our group are November 26th to December 3rd, but other dates are available . Currently we are adding additional dates in Feb. School vacation week and probably the week after. (I might be going in July as well. But Stacey goes down often.)  Just come for general info now and you can figure out which dates are best for you later. 

Each has it's pros and cons. It all depends on what you're looking for. But all are amazingly fun and you'll never forget this adventure. Guarantee it!!!!

And one thing you get on these that you won't get from any online booking site - and this is the best part: a meetup organizer that has experience in the area to show you a good time. It's like having your own local tour guide--because you do!!!!

UPDATE - OPTION 4 IS WHAT WE ARE RESERVING FOR OUR GROUP TRIP FROM NOV 26TH - DEC 3RD. THE HOUSES AREN'T GUARANTEED UNTIL WE GET ENOUGH DEPOSITS TO MAKE A PRETTY HEFTY DOWN PAYMENT. BUT REST ASSURED. THEY'RE ALL PRETTY DAMN NICE. 


.......................................


Please look at our 5 options below:

Option 1 - Surf Hostel 

Don't let the name fool you. This is Raw Costa Rican beauty at its best. Delicious food, gracious hosts, RIGHT on the black sand beach of rural of the Central American Coast.


(That was me enjoying my morning tea at the hostel last December)

Rustic yet clean and comfortable, and right on the beach.


The food is amazing and the staff is super accommodating and sweet. Still close to all the attractions and adventures. The door to this room is about 25 feet from where I had my tea in the top photo. Gorgeous!


...................................................................................................


Option 2 - OstionalTurtle Lodge. 

A step up. very clean upgraded accommodations in Ostional.  Very clean with AC and private baths.


...........................................................................

Option 3 - Azul Ocean Club 5 Star resort


 A luxury resort not far from these places and all the attractions with high end restaurants and accommodations. It's a 5 star, well-manicured resort close to all the activities and other venues so we can still play together.


...........................................................................

Option 4 - Surf House in Nosara

Nosara is a coastal surf community full of restaurants, night life, gorgeous beaches, and Costa Rican activities such as surfing, zip lining, yoga, horseback riding and a whole lot more. The advantage to this gem is that you're right in the middle of all the action. You will be able to walk to many of the activities you're looking for. This house is not a definite. It depends on how many people sign up and how quickly, which is why I am eager to get this ball rolling. The quicker you guys sign up and pay, the more likely it is that we land a nice house like this near the water.


..............................................................................


Option 5 - Adults Only 

All Inclusive Occidental Grand Papagayo Resort

Closer to the airport, this all inclusive offers one stop shopping for those who want a short commute from the airport and a more relaxing time away. Costa Rican adventures are still a step away, but this is for those of you who are looking for a less active and more "polished" vacation. 

..............................................................................

ACTIVITIES

In addition to these resorts are our activities. Some will be included depending on your package. All can be added.


Sunset horseback ride on the beach


Yoga with a view


Stand Up Paddleboarding....or sitting. Either way, the view is amazing...


Surfing Lessons 


View the wildlife.... Ever want to moon your friends in a rainforest waterfall?


Or Ziplining
results.name: Costa Rican Adventure Info Session Rockland Edition

This is the fourth installment of my ongoing series of visits to the Citizen Public House and Oyster Bar which I consider our unofficial home base. It is a place of good cheer, great spirits and maybe we'll spot a roasted pig in the vicinity. If you've never joined us here then you are missing an experience.

The test consists of:
A) Can you get here?
B) Can you name a whiskey that they can serve you?
C) Can you drink said whiskey?

The Citizen Pub is a modern neighborhood tavern located behind Fenway Park and a 10 minute walk from Kenmore Station. Chef Brian Reyelt’s menu is a fresh twist on Tavern Cuisine. The bar features craft cocktails, world-class wines, a selection of over 200 whiskeys, including between 5 and 8 hand selected single barrels. William has personal experience with many of them and has a Citizens-provided list as proof. For those that are more a beer drinker than the rest they do have a respectable assortment of IPAs, Lagers, Ales, Porters, and Stouts.

More info can be found here:
http://www.citizenpub.com/about/
OR
https://www.zomato.com/boston/citizen-public-house-and-oyster-bar-boston

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
What if you want to sell your notes? Perhaps you just want to get in as a note broker and flip some notes quickly for lump sums of cash. Others might just find they need more liquidity down the road, or there is a big life expense that arises.

If you’ve got a good and valuable note you should find no shortage of note buyers. But, before you sell off the valuable asset and income producing investment you’ve acquired or created consider that you may be able to sell a part of your note.

There are many partial note options, including:

·  Selling a number of upcoming payments

·  Selling a percentage of each payment

Who will buy my note?

How to sell your notes:

Those that want to get more aggressive in routinely selling notes, and to maximize their returns get proactive about marketing and promoting their notes.

results.description:
Tricia Tierney: 

http://www.meetup.com...

https://www.gofundme.com/22gjj7w


­

a member of NSS sent me an email with this information and asking for our help during this difficult time she is going through. 

GO FUND ME – TRICIA TIERNEY - # THANK A TEACHER

Go to:  https://www.gofundme....

­ to donate or Google “gofundme”, Search “ Patricia Tierney” to get to the facebook link and page to donate . THANK YOU. 

Life has been most difficult since she learned of the terminal cancer in July, 2015; going through three different regiments of chemo drugs, each with their own problems; developing a dangerous problem with brain bleeds which requires surgery and could cause a stroke during the operation; and trying to handle everything living alone. 


Gratefully, some family is only a phone call away. Anything that can be donated will be thankfully welcomed.

If a "handyman" is not able to donate monetarily, but could donate his time and talent for repairing and cleaning up an old house, she would be most appreciative. 

A Lynn Public Schools veteran teacher of 30 years has been diagnosed with a terminal cancer and needs surgery on her brain in May, 2016. # Thank A Teacher


Patricia (Hart) Tierney is a retired Lynn Public Schools elementary teacher and life-long resident of Lynn. She taught both regular classrooms, then became a music specialist for the last 24 years of her career. She touched the lives of thousands of underprivileged children by sharing her love and enthusiasm for music. Outside of the classroom, Tricia enjoys traveling and teaching water aerobics at many local fitness centers.


In July of 2015 a tumor was found in each of her lungs. They were biopsied and found to be malignant metastasized transitional cell carcinoma from the urothelial cancer in her bladder. This was her seventh cancer in the past four years, and it is terminal. She was being treated with chemotherapy. She was getting other symptoms of concern as blurry vision, only seeing half of her cell phone screen, and brain bleeds seen on CAT scans and MRI’s. She went for neurological tests in April, 2016 and the neurologist found missing connections from the arteries to the veins on the left side of her brain. This is what was causing the symptoms for her. She has an AV Dural Fistula. The misconnections have formed on the hard matter that covers the brain to make things worse. Surgery is on 5/24/2016.


Tricia considered herself very lucky to still be teaching water aerobics at the Burbank YMCA in Reading; the Torigian YMCA in Peabody; the Ipswich Family YMCA; and the Beverly Athletic Club. She also was the director of a nursery for toddlers at the Melrose Unitarian Universalist Church. Tricia’s oncologist requested that she resign all jobs in February, 2016 as her tumors had grown on her previous chemo medication. Reluctantly, she did. She now has no weekly income. The funds will be used immediately and continuously to replace her salary to take care of daily living needs. Please help by donating if you are able, then sharing this campaign with your friends and contacts.


Let’s rock this fund and help Tricia become one of the everyday MIRACLES. Let the Lord be in the surgeon’s hands during surgery and put an end to the bleeding on the left side of her brain. Tricia has way too much living to do with uplifting people who know how to have a good time. Let’s put an end to five years of sickness and say hello again to joy, excitement, and LIFE!

Thank you for your time and compassion.


Be safe, yours truly Eirini Kay
results.how_to_find_us: https://www.gofundme.com/22gjj7w
results.name: Tricia Tierney a member of NSS needs our help well she fights for her life

results.description:
Adams National Historic Park Tour


 This is a full afternoon event that takes us on a two hour private guided trolley tour of the birthplace homes of Presidents John and John Quincy Adams, and also the Old House at Peace Field, home to the four Adams generations, from 1788 to 1927. 


 After the Guided trolley tour we will have a private tour of the Adams Crypts located at the Church of the Presidents, across the street from the visitors center.


"Quincy, Massachusetts, is proud to be distinguished as the birthplace lifetime home, and final resting place of the second and sixth Presidents of the United States, who each played crucial roles in securing our nation's independence and making our democracy strong.  The tombs of John Adams and John Quincy Adams, alongside those of First Ladies Abigail Adams, and Louisa Catherine Adams, rest within the crypt at United First Parish Church, Church of the Presidents, which was their place of family worship."


 This event is on May 24th, and the cost is $25 per person.


 We meet at noon at the visitors center, in The Galleria at Presidents Place, (Quincy College), we will enjoy a brown bag lunch, attend a 1pm short film, catch our 1:45 Trolley and will end at approximately 4:30.


 The visitors center, where we begin and end our tour, is across the street from the Red Line T station, Quincy Center stop.

There is a great HBO special available to watch free on Comcast "on demand"   This would be a great way to prepare for this excursion!

http://www.hbo.com/john-adams

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

BCBB is excited to announce the 4th installment in our seminar series. May 24th at 5:30PM, join us in the incredible Microsoft NERD Commons function space for free pizza, a cash bar, all your friends from BCBB, and 2 very exciting speakers.

To get into the NERD space, show a photo ID at the front door and ask for directions to the Commons room.


For this edition of the BCBB seminar series, we're welcoming two incredible speakers, both very well known in the computational biology community. 

Peter Park, assistant professor of biomedical informatics at Harvard Medical School (bio), will be discussing his research in computational analysis of genomic data to answer important questions in epigenetics and cancer genetics, his talk title is “Mutational analysis of single neurons using whole-genome sequencing". 

Chris Dagdigian, co-founder and principle consultant at BioTeam (bio), will present a seminar covering trends in research IT that even the most IT-challenged computational biologist will benefit from. 

A big thank you to BioTeam for sponsoring this event. 

Agenda:

• 5:30-6:10: Networking, pizza, and cash bar.


• 6:10-6:15: Welcome from the organizers.


• 6:15-6:45: Peter Park (Talk title: “Mutational analysis of single neurons using whole-genome sequencing") 

• 6:45-7:15: Chris Dagdigian (Talk title: TBA)


• 7:15-9:00: Cash bar and networking (note: last call is at 8:30)

About our sponsor BioTeam:

BioTeam is a professional services consulting company specializing the area of science and information technology. We have a well-established history of providing complete, and forward-thinking solutions and products to the life sciences. BioTeam has a cross-section of expertise that includes classical laboratory scientific training, applications development, informatics, large data center installations, high performance computing (HPC), enterprise and scientific network engineering, high-volume and high-performance storage, public cloud orchestration, in-depth training, research.

results.description:
User growth is the #1 problem for our Lean Startup Circle community.  It's really hard to get new users.  An amazing new product can't help anyone until the people hear that it exists. 

The media can expose a product to a new set of consumers, but founders don't always know how and when to get coverage.


Olivia Vanni from BostInno Kaite Rosa and from VentureFizzwill share how they decide what to report on, who to write about, and when a startup is ready for media.


6:00 PM Networking

6:30 PM Panel begins

7:30 Open Q&A

Panelists will speak about:

• How do you pick who you write about?

• Where do the best stories come from?

• How do you decide when a start-up is news-worthy?

• Who do you think of when you think of as "up and coming" startups in Boston?

• What do you think is different about Boston start-ups compared to start-ups in other cities?

• What makes the most compelling stories?

• What is the best way to get noticed?

• Do you pay attention to Press releases? 

• What format should people use to contact you?

Want to submit a question for the panelists ahead of time? Submit it here.

Kaite Rosa is Director, Content & Marketing at VentureFizz, a digital platform covering technology, entrepreneurship, and career inspiration in Boston, where she's responsible for leading the editorial and marketing directions.

An award-winning writer, editor, and content strategist with nearly a decade of professional experience, Kaite specializes in content marketing, corporate communications, and thought leadership for tech companies. She has held content-driven roles at leading Boston-area companies including Virgin Pulse, Lionbridge, and Brafton, and has reported for New York City-based online publications Mobile Marketer, Mobile Commerce Daily, and Luxury Daily.

Kaite lives outside of Boston with her husband and their rescue dog, Marlee.



Olivia Vanni is a staff writer for BostInno, focusing on topics linked to student and alumni entrepreneurs, young innovators and the next generation of tech talent. Prior to BostInno, Vanni was a copywriter for local startups, worked as a news and content writer for tech clients throughout the country and dealt in enterprise SaaS sales at NetSuite. She has a B.A. from Holy Cross in Worcester and the University of Bologna, Italy.
results.name: BostInno and VentureFizz Share Tips About How to get Startup Media Coverage

REGISTRATION IS NOW OPEN for the spring season of the Jack’s Abby Social Tennis League! This year we’re pleased to announce an expanded offering of locations. 

Site Locations, Match Times and Starting Dates:

South Boston, MA @Joe Moakley Park: Wednesdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 11th) 

South Boston, MA @ Joe Moakley Park: Thursdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 12th) 

Medford, MA @Tufts University: Wednesdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 11th)

Medford, MA @Tufts University: Thursdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 12th)

Brookline, MA @ Waldstein Park: Tuesdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 10th) 

Brookline, MA @ Waldstein Park: Thursdays from 6-9 pm (Begins May 12th) 

League Format:

The format for the Jack’s Abby Social Tennis League will be the same as last year – 7 weeks, 6 teams, 1-hour long matches, and restaurant specials after on-court play. Our first week will be a tennis jamboree open to everyone, weeks 2-6 will be round-robin team competition, week 7 will be an individual tournament unless utilized for rained-out match makeups.

Registration Details:

Registration for the league is through the Teamsnap mobile app or Teamsnap.com. Teamsnap is an easy-to-use social sports league application that:

1. Helps you save time communicating with your team on your phone 2. Provides you auto-notifications on schedule updates, changes and cancellations.  3. Allows you to send messages, send updates, track matches, share photos and more. Jack’s Abby Social Tennis League smartphone users are encouraged to download the Teamsnap application on their mobile devices.

USE THE LINK BELOW TO SIGN UP FOR TEAMSNAP AND REGISTER FOR THIS SPRING SEASON OF THE JACK’S ABBY SOCIAL TENNIS LEAGUE: https://go.teamsnap.com/divisions/72836/registration/24517/register/new

Don’t forget our referral program – We discount your registration fee $10.00 for every player who joins the league off your recommendation! 

Site Coordinator Search:

Interested in joining the Jack’s Abby Social Tennis League team?  Become a site coordinator, or team captain! Being a site coordinator is fairly simple, and often fun! If interested, please email [masked] to discuss the location you’re interested in coordinating!

Thanks everyone – I look forward to seeing you on court this spring!

Christo

results.description:
OPEN CARDS AND BOARD GAME NIGHT

ANTHING GOES TONIGHT - bring your board games, and your card games like Sorry, Yahtzee, Clue, Domino, Scrabble, Apple to Apples, Monopoly, Wizard, etc...

                        Tonight we'll play them all!

   Bring your decks of cards and let the games begin!

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a open cards and board game night.  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play whatever there is.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds (Before 6pm) can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

BGN Fans,  


We're excited to bring you May's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by OpenView and Downeast Cider House

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. OpenView Partners are giving away loads of swag and has offered to match every donation so your $5 donation is going a lot further.

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGN12 and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

Our games include:

• Settlers of Catan

• Race to the Galaxy

• Dominion

• Marvel Legendary

• Succession

• Puerto Rico

• DiXit

• San Juan 

• Or bring your own! 

SPONSORS

East Coast Product is the fastest most efficient way to build the right digital product to get your startup to it's next milestone. We are a product accelerator specializing in growth stage startups, helping them through strategy and execution. 

OpenView is an expansion stage venture firm helping build software companies like Instructure, Kareo, Datadog and Expensify into market leaders. Through our Expansion Platform, we help companies hire the best talent, acquire and retain the right customers and partner with industry leaders so they can dominate their markets. Our focus on the expansion stage makes us uniquely suited to provide truly tailored operational support to our portfolio companies. Learn more about OpenView at openviewpartners.com.

results.description:
Hi Everybody!

We have an in-depth talk and demo by Chris Fregly for this month's special presentation night, with sponsorship for both space and food/drink generously provided by Spotify!

Check out the details below. I imagine this will be a popular event, so we are limiting RSVPs to make sure people can fit in the space.

Cheers!
Nick, Yana, Matt, and Cao

Meetup Agenda:

• 6:00 - 6:45: Food, drink, and mingling

• 6:45 - 7:00: Opening remarks and sponsor message


• 7:00 - 9:00: Feature talk


Feature Talk: Real-time Aggregations, Approximations, Similarities, and Recommendations at Scale using Spark Streaming, ML, GraphX, Kafka, Cassandra, Docker, CoreNLP, Word2Vec, LDA, and Twitter Algebird

Talk Abstract: Starting with a live, interactive demo generating audience-specific recommendations, we'll dive deep into each of the key components including NiFi, Kafka, Stanford CoreNLP, Docker, Word2Vec, LDA, Twitter Algebird, Spark Streaming, SQL, ML, GraphX.  As a bonus, we'll discuss the latest Netflix Recommendations Pipeline and related open source projects.

Talk Agenda:

• Intro

• Live, Interactive Recommendations Demo


    • Spark Streaming, ML, GraphX, Kafka, Cassandra, Docker, CoreNLP, Word2Vec, LDA, and Twitter Algebird  (advancedspark.com)

• Types of Similarity

    • Euclidean vs. Non-Euclidean Similarity

    • Jaccard Similarity

    • Cosine Similarity

    • LogLikelihood Similarity

    • Edit Distance

• Text-based Similarities and Analytics

    • Word2Vec

    • LDA Topic Extraction

    • TextRank

• Similarity-based Recommendations

    • User-to-User

    • Content-based, Item-to-Item (Amazon)

    • Collaborative-based, User-to-Item  (Netflix)

    • Graph-based, Item-to-Item "Pathways" (Spotify)

• Aggregations, Approximations, and Similarities at Scale

    • Twitter Algebird

    • MinHash and Bucketing

    • Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH)

    • BloomFilters

    • CountMin Sketch

    • HyperLogLog

• Q & A 


Speaker Bio: Chris Fregly is a Research Engineer @ Flux Capacitor AI in SF, an Apache Spark Contributor, and a Netflix Open Source Committer. 

Chris is also the founder of the global Advanced Apache Spark Meetup and author of the upcoming book, Advanced Spark @ advancedspark.com. 

Previously, Chris was a Data Solutions Engineer at Databricks and a Streaming Data Engineer at Netflix.

When Chris isn’t contributing to Spark and other open source projects, he’s creating book chapters, slides, and demos to share knowledge with his peers at Meetups and conferences throughout the world.

results.description:
Walkers & Joggers Welcome

May 3, 2016 @ 6:15PM (every Tuesday and Thursday night for 9 wks)

We're here to help you achieve your goal of beginning to run your first 5K. Too many people have been turned off of running simply by trying to start off too fast. Their bodies rebel, and they wind up miserable, wondering why anyone would possibly want to run in the first place. You should ease into your 5K training plan gradually. In fact, the beginners' program we outline here is less of a running regimen than a walking and jogging program. The idea is to transform you from couch potato to runner, getting you to begin running a 5K or 3.1 miles and on a regular basis in just two months.  Each session should take about 20 or 30 minutes, three times a week. That just happens to be the same amount of moderate exercise recommended by numerous studies for optimum fitness. This program will get you fit. 

We will be meeting twice a week, so you SHOULD train the 3rd time on your own either on Saturday or Sunday to keep with the schedule.  Remember to bring your sneakers and some water.
  http://www.coolrunning.com/engine/2/2_3/181.shtml


Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel. We will train if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle. Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case.

results.description:
Thank you to WeWork for hosting the space for this event, and for the Cloud 66 team sponsoring food and primary presentation.


Presentation: Habitus - a Docker Built System Hosted on AWS

Abstract:
Building a real-world application in containers takes much more than just following simple ADD and RUN steps. Anyone who's built a Docker image before, will know how complex the workflow can get. From how to support multi-tenancy builds, keeping attack surfaces small when creating compile time libraries, to finding solutions for how to expose SSH keys without leaving traces in the image, our own development team at Cloud 66 shared many of these challenges.

To solve this problem, we built Habitus on AWS as an open source build flow tool for Docker. During this talk Khash will introduce you to Habitus, explain how it enables developers to combine multiple Dockerfiles into complex build and deployment workflows, and how you can deploy Docker in production with Cloud 66 and AWS.

About Khash Sajadi:
Khash is founder and CEO of Cloud 66 that provides a DevOps as a service for Rails and for Docker on any cloud provider. Over the past 20 years, Khash has worked at different roles from Vice President at Lehman Brothers to CTO of startups at Silicon Valley. Khash is passionate about developer tools and how they can improve daily workflow. Khash has a BSc in mechanical engineering and MSc in management of software projects.

-------------------------------------


Presentation: Development Workflows Using Docker

Abstract:  Komand's dev team uses Docker to ensure our development environment closely mirrors production.  
With Docker, we enjoy the advantages of an efficient, low-cost local development environment while avoiding the inconsistencies typical of those environments.
I'll show the tips and tricks we use to simplify our Docker builds and streamline our development workflow. I'll discuss our experiences with automation tools like docker-compose and gulp as well as ways to dramatically speed up container file synchronization in non-native Docker environments such as MacOS.

About Jim Salem: Jim Salem is CTO of Komand where we are building an easy-to-use IT security orchestration and management platform. Jim is a pioneer in Internet services and distributed computing. He has held senior technical leadership roles at Datto, Acquia, Endurance International Group, Intuit, BBN, and Thinking Machines. He holds an EECS degree from MIT.


-------------------------------------


About WeWork:
"WeWork is a community of creators. We transform buildings into collaborative workspaces. Our mission is to help companies grow by providing them with not just beautiful space but benefits, amenities,
and community they need to focus on their business, all on very flexible terms. We currently have over 50,000 people working out of our communities worldwide, and over 2,600 members here in Boston. Sign up for a tour at WeWork."

-------------------------------------

Contact Mark Annati, the moderator, at [masked] with interest in sponsoring (location/food) and presenting at future meetups. Thank you.

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
Hey Security of Things MeetUp members. A reminder that the folks at Fitbit have extended an invitation to the Security of Things Meetup: an opportunity to meet with Fitbit's product security team tomorrow evening, Tuesday, May 24th, at the Fitbit offices in downtown Boston! 

This is a great opportunity to talk with the folks responsible for securing the hottest wearable technology in the market right now. Fitbit isn't just a wearable activity monitor: its a sensing platform for a wide range of health monitoring activities: from fitness and weight loss to sleep monitoring and social networking. 

Come hear about how the Fitbit team addresses the security and privacy challenges of its growing and enthusiastic user base, while also developing next generation features to keep their technology relevant and cutting edge. 

I hope you'll be able to join us for this special Security of Things MeetUp next Tuesday. 

I look forward to seeing you there! 

Paul

results.name: Tomorrow (TUE): Meet The Fitbit Security Team!

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog
results.name: The Tuesday Track Workout

results.description:
In this introductory session you will learn how to create simple stream processing solution with Azure Stream Analytics (ASA) that collect, analyze and visualize  data from IoT devices in real-time. We will use a real-world, Internet of Things (IoT) use-case to demonstrate how to build your solution quickly and economically.


Azure Stream Analytics (ASA) is a fully managed, cost effective real-time event processing engine that helps to unlock deep insights from data. Stream Analytics makes it easy to set up real-time analytic computations on data streaming from devices, sensors, web sites, social media, applications, infrastructure systems, and more.


We are going to learn how to: 

• Setup and Configure ASA in Azure Portal.

• Create Azure Event Hub to stream the data.

• Create ASA Jobs to process IoT steaming data.

• Use the Stream Analytics query language.

• Create Power BI real-time report and visualize the data.

Speaker: 

Slava Kokaev Solution Architect, Mentor, Speaker and Boston Microsoft Business Intelligence User Group Leader specializing in Business Intelligence, Data Analytics and  Big Data solutions.

Pizza and Soda (Free) provided Slalom

Parking: There is free <a>MIT parking lot on Hayward Street</a>.  There is also a free lot across from the Alewife T stop at the <a>Summer Shack</a>. 

Note: 

6:20 PM ~ 6:55 PM Pizza and Networking time.

7:00 PM ~ 8:45 PM Main Session
results.name: Real-Time Analytics with Azure Stream Analytics and Power BI

We're a group of friendly folks who just love playing and getting together on a regular basis.  Our skills range from advanced beginner through experienced, and we're happy to help a 'newbie' or two learn the game.  Please bring a set if you have one; everyone will also need their own mah jong card.  Note that we will be playing American-style Mah jong, which is slightly different from Chinese mah jong.  American-style requires a mah jong card and uses jokers.  

We'd like to start the games at 6:30 promptly; feel free to come early and grab a bite from the Wegmans' cafe.  I'm typically upstairs around 6:00 to eat, meet, and greet!

Hope to see you on Tuesday nights!

--Jill

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer (optional). A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

Find us: http://p.irateship.com/treasuremap.html

results.description:
Let's mix it up and meet eligible single professionals in Boston!  We will provide the atmosphere, event hosts, and appetizers.  You can let us know who caught your eye and we will email you with any matches within 24 hours!

Event Details:

Arrive, pick up your nametag and score card, grab a beverage, enjoy a complimentary bite to eat, and meet new singles!

If someone catches your eye, or you have a great conversation with them, write their name on your score card. Turn it in at the end of the night, and if they selected you too, we will pass along your email address so you can keep the conversation going.  Want to take matters into your own hands? Then exchange cards or social profiles right there!  

We have an icebreaker organized to help you get chatting.  When you register, let us know a fun fact about yourself.  When you check in, someone from the opposite sex will get a note card with that fact on it... and when they find you, they get a point towards our door prize.  The first ten people with 2 points will win (and we will be ready if there is a tie).  Don't want to participate? Leave that question blank at sign up.

This event is designed to be fun, and give you a few nudges towards speaking and meeting new singles in Boston.

Appetizers are provided.  Cash bar.

Gentlemen! Use code "meetup" when you register in advance: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/single-mingle-tickets-24741551647

Door price is $20 cash.  Advance registration is being strongly encouraged so enough food is ordered and check in is efficient.

results.description:
I had to cover a lot... so please read all the text below.

Here's a video to get you started. Don't let the length intimidate you. Just focus on the first few minutes but do as much as you like.


http://youtu.be/aV8dS2m9Adc

I'm really excited about this event. I've been working on this for a few months... 2 Hanson Rec Commission meetings later, increasing my liability insurance, signing my life away in a contract, approval from the town administrator and what seems to be 50 trips to this place. I have permission for us to do a series of Beginner Salsa Lessons. (swing lessons to follow if this is a success) I'll post 2 to start so please help me make these a success by giving it a shot. You'll have a blast trust me!


Our instructors have years of dancing experience, plenty of personality and of course I'll be providing the sound system with some great music. I've taken group lessons before and the music was too fast, esp in the open dance time. So we're going to gear this to 2 left footed neanderthal dancers like me.


The Hanson Rec Commission members are very excited about this and want us to succeed. So thank them when you see them at the event.


Our plan is to have weekly dances for 2 hours. The first hour will be a lesson and the 2nd an open dance. These will be geared for beginners so don't be afraid. To You Salsa veterans - please come because we'll need your help too... and you can show off during the open dance hour.


Once per month we'll be having a bartender for a 4 hour dance. A little wine might loosen up the hips a little ;-) This first dance will be for 2 hours. The 2nd dance lesson on Feb 26th will have the bar and be open for 4 hours. (7-11 see the post for the 26th)


Gender equity? of course ladies bring a man with you but for the first few lessons gender equity won't be a huge issue. Nevertheless, put the pressure on the men you know, in the group and out, to make it to this. It's gonna be a blast !

Please post questions below.

DIRECTIONS - Please use your GPS. For those of you who have never been, Hanson is only 30 min from Plymouth and Braintree. And only 15 min from Hanover or Brockton. See it's nice and centrally located. Camp Kiwannee is right on rt 58 with plenty of parking.

The cost is $10 per person - a very reasonable price. FYI - I don't make a dime on this. Camp Kiwanee gets a percentage of the door and the remainder goes to the instructors and those working the door.


Here's a few pictures of Needles Lodge at Camp Kiwanee. It's a gem right here in our little one-horse town of Hanson.

That's only about 2/3rds of the room. They were rehearsing a play in the other third. I'll get better pictures up there soon. But you get the idea.

the entrance... love this place... Old world charm...

results.description:
Please join us in person or via live-stream (http://www.naturaldharma.org/live-teachings/) for an evening of practice and discussion with NDF meditation teacher, Bob Morrison.

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/5/0/4/8/event_450320552.jpegBob is a writer living in the Boston area. Since meeting the late Nyoshul Khenpo Rinpoche in 1994, he has studied and practiced the Dzogchen teachings of Tibetan Buddhism, primarily with his main teachers: Lama Surya Das, Lama John Makransky, Lama Willa Miller, Charles Genoud, Brendan Kennedy and Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche. As a meditation teacher with Natural Dharma Fellowship since its founding, he co-directs (with Camille Hykes) NDF’s margha program, which offers year-long trainings in natural meditation and bodhicitta practices.He is also a guiding teacher with Foundation for Active Compassion, sharing the Innate Love and Wisdom practices developed by Lama John Makransky, as well as host of NDF’s and FAC’s Green Tara sadhana practice group. As an avid hiker, his special interests include the awakening power of nature and, as a cancer survivor, helping others embrace the challenges of cancer as spiritual opportunities.
