results.description:
What is Folk Psychology?  (or What is it like to be Human?)

Folk psychology, as philosophers have come to use the phrase, is almost identical with common sense psychology – the psychology all of us (friend, citizen, salesman, lawyer, politician) employ in our everyday life.

Folk psychology refers to a social fact of which we are well aware: We understand how other people think well enough to predict and explain their behavior. This fact is so obvious that we ignore it most of the time. 

There are an indefinite number of examples.  If your friend accept a dinner invitation, you can 'predict' when your friend will come to dinner. You can explain why you and others voted for Sanders. Why did John go into the kitchen? He thought there was a can of beer in the kitchen and he was thirsty.

Folk psychology was ‘discovered’ about 50 years ago. Since then it has been a major interest for philosophers. However, there is still considerable disagreement as to how it should be characterized. This turns out to be more difficult than it might seem. The reason is that the definition a philosopher uses affects the theory he or she gives to explain folk psychology.

One of the reasons for the interest in folk psychology is that some philosophers claim that, “our common-sense understanding of psychological states and processes is deeply mistaken [and] . . . certain common-sense mental states, such as beliefs and desires, do not exist.”  http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/materialism-eliminative/

There are two competing theories of folk psychology discussed in the reference articles:  The folk theory of mind (or theory-theory) and simulation theory.  These theories proport to give an account of the processes and mechanisms underlying folk psychology.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~
Donations: To help support the Democracy Center, a voluntary donation will be requested at the meeting. 


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~
References: 

A brief (3 pages) introduction is given by L R Baker in The MIT Encyclopedia of the Cognitive Sciences (1999).
http://files.meetup.com/331299/%27Folk%20Psychology%27%20Baker%20%281999%29.pdf

A historical introduction is given by Nichols in Encyclopedia of Cognitive Science (2002).
http://dingo.sbs.arizona.edu/~snichols/Papers/FolkPsychologyECS.pdf

A thorough comparison of the main theories is given by Stich & Nichols in Blackwell Guide to Philosophy of Mind, (2003).
http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~stich/Publications/Papers/FolkPsychology.pdf
results.name: What is Folk Psychology?

Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (Southeastern Hiking Club)

Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Abington/Weymouth Town Line, Rt 18, see exact address above

$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.

15 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Small - Womens 4-7 or Mens 3-6
Medium - Womens[masked] Mens[masked]
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11

Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- We meet in the Zass Zumba Studio, look for the yellow sign in the strip mall

- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal (or drink too much) up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, it may run a few minutes past the hour, it's ok to go inside and wait.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May.

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
This is part of our meetup series throughout the year to visit specific neighborhoods in Boston and Cambridge, and perhaps later branching out into other towns and cities. This is meant to be both about getting to know parts of the city better, as well as being a photography challenge, because these are unglamorous targets compared to, say, the Zakim bridge, which forces you to find opportunities to portrait the neighborhoods and architecture in a compelling way. Use this as an opportunity to create a project for yourself (Boston brownstone entry stairs? Night street photography?)

The paradigm for these meetups is to provide you with basic information and some images about the neighborhood, meet as a group to briefly discuss the opportunities, but then spread out to investigate the area, rather than moving in a group. If you do not feel comfortable walking on your own, make sure to tag along with someone in groups of 2-3. Take a look at our last neighborhoods meetup to get an idea of what one can find.

Our neighborhood for this evening is Beacon Hill, which has several very nice, tiny cobble stone roads, lots of old and interesting architecture, backyard stairways and loads of intriguing windows, doorways, nooks and crannies.

At the east edge of Beacon Hill is the MA state house, an often photographed building with its golden dome: try to make it look more interesting than the average tourist snapshot. And if there is still energy left, cross over to the Esplanade with its waterfront views of Cambridge, small pedestrian bridges and boats.


Suggested equipment: tripod, camera, intervalometer (star trails over Acorn Street??), super-wide lenses to medium zooms (to reach those backyard views), good footwear, the roads and walkways are uneven and it's quite a bit of walking.


The sun will set at 8:08, we will meet at the end of civil twilight, the moon will be 66% full and up all night.


Inspirations below.
results.name: Boston Neighborhoods: Beacon Hill

results.description:
Join us as we explore the Town of Lincoln's Conservation Land via its extensive trail system.  


On this 9-10 mile loop we’ll visit Adams Woods, Walden Pond, pass through farmland, the grounds of the Codman Estate, and Codman Communty Farm.

Expect to spend up to a minimum of five hours on this trek; it could take longer.

Level:  EASY for distance, with an elevation gain of 500'.   Factor in your own ability to walk 9-10 miles.

As there's only space for about 16-20 cars carpooling is recommended.  To arrange for carpooling post the request under the Comments section but make the arrangements via the Messenger.  Click on any member's profile page, then click on 'message'.

Dogs are not welcome on BSOT events, nor are guests.  If you would like to bring a non-member they must first apply to become a member.  Then, if they are approved,  they then must RSVP YES.  No exceptions.  Please observe these rules. 

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events. 

I will send out an email the day before the event with the weather forecast, last minute reminders, etc. 

Extreme weather conditions cancel this event.

The guest list is limited to 16 due to limited parking.

Cell Phones and Electronic Devices:

I ask that while on the BSOT events that I host you limit your use of electronic devices to the following activities:

Map My Hike or other Hiking Apps

Location Services

Cameras

Weather Apps

One of the pleasant features of being out and about is that we all get away from the constant distractions of cell phones.  I ask that while on the events I host you:

Don't use your phone (of course! I make exceptions for emergencies and calling a taxi/Uber if you can't make it back on foot!)

Don't listen to the radio.

Don't play music.

Thank you in advance for respecting this request

http://lincolnconservation.org


http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-north/walden-pond-state-reservation.html


http://www.historicnewengland.org/historic-properties/homes/codman-estate 

The Fine Print:


Duration: Approximately 5 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day.

The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

I will find out the trail conditions the day before and then send them to all who have RSVPd yes via an email. But, use your own judgment.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated Easy. You should be able to stay with the group. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree (woof!). If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below:

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you have read and agree to adhere to the safety standards detailed @ http://www.hikesafe.com/; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.
results.name: Lincoln Conservation Land Trek

results.description:
Please note that we may change the location and time for each Saturday run. Make sure to check the time/location on Friday every week.

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc.  


Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
Follow this link to register for Organic Practice Beekeeping and don't forget to RSVP on this Meetup page too.


Why do treatment free beekeeping?

The answer is simply a philosophy that goes something like this ~ any time you treat your hive for any kind of pest or disease you are selecting for bees that cannot take care of that pest or disease without your help. By continuing on the path of using treatments you end up breeding stronger pests and diseases resistant to treatments, instead of breeding better bees resistant to pests and disease.

Anita will help us to understand what bees do and don’t need from us so that they can be happy, productive and healthy without the use of intrusive treatments.

About Anita: Anita is a Biologist and MA State Bee Inspector who maintains approximately 30 honey bee hives.  She started out as a backyard beekeeper full of enthusiasm and trepidation with only a single hive on my rooftop. Her passion and quest for beekeeping knowledge led me on an adventure across America that would change my path forever. You can read about this journey since day one here on her beekeeping blog.

About iFarm: ifarm utilizes a restored 19th century farmstead to reconnect the individual with the earth. The goal is to provide diverse educational experiences that utilize core values of sustainability, rejuvenation, and thoughtful design which both individuals and communities can incorporate into their own environment, experiences and life.
results.name: Organic Practice Beekeeping with Anita Deeley

Mcmansions, used car lots, and prisons
Saturday - May 28

Ride Type: Cue Sheet, Map, GPS

Times and Routes: 10:00AM 44 miles long and 25 mile short

Leaders: Barbara Martin [masked] before 9PM), Gene Ho [masked] anytime)

Description: Starting from the Waban section of Newton, we'll ride west thru the Mcmansion lands of Wellesley, Weston, Dover, and Sherborn to visit the world's largest indoor used car lot and the Mass Women's Correctional Facility. Expect to see quaint houses we can't afford and animals who eat and live better than we do. The dealer welcomes offers on used cars but to see the inside of the prison requires indictment, prosecution, and conviction by your friends in law enforcement. You're on your own here. To satisfy our input and output needs, there are Dunkin Donuts at the start and the halfway point. For those without GPS, print the maps and cue sheets from the links above. We'll have a few copies at the start but our printer's ink is running dry and legibility will be iffy.

Start: 1172 Beacon st, Newton

Directions: Exit 21 East from Rt 128, 0.2m East on Rt 16, bear right onto Beacon St at the light. Continue on Beacon St for 2.1m. Right turn at #1172, a 4 story brick office building. Park or meet in the parking lot behind #1172.

results.description:
The Outdoor Discovery Schools begin on-water instruction on the historic Dedham Water Trail for Kayak, Stand Up Paddle Board and Kayak Fly-Fishing starting May 28, 2016. 

Go to www.llbean.com/dedham or www.llbean.com/adventure to see the full schedule.

Registration on the L.L. Bean website is required to attend this event. Visit www.llbean.com/dedham to reserve your spot.


90 minute classes begin at varied times both Saturday and Sunday.

Description:

Our Kayaking Discovery Course is a great way to learn the basic paddling techniques and safety skills of this popular sport. Exploring nature in a kayak is a healthy and fun way to enjoy the outdoors. Our course begins with a brief introduction and safety talk from our friendly paddling instructors, who will share their knowledge gained from years of kayaking. They'll outfit you with a personal flotation device (PFD), kayak and paddling equipment, giving you insight on the best ways to set up your boat. Then, you'll receive instruction on a variety of paddling techniques.

After you feel comfortable on the water, you'll set out in a kayak on a guided, interpretive tour with your group. You'll experience the freedom of skimming across the water, learning about the ecosystem and history of the area.

All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

Prerequisite: None

Activity level: Easy

Minimum age: 8 (14 and under with parent or guardian)

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending.  Go to www.llbean.com/dedham to sign up!

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed.

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

90 minute classes begin at varied times both Saturday and Sunday.

Description:

Discover how easy it is to balance on top of the water. Our paddle boarding starter course is an excellent opportunity to learn the basic strokes and skills you'll need for maneuvering a paddle board, allowing you to explore scenic lakes, coves and inlets.

Our course begins with a brief introduction and safety talk from our friendly paddling instructors, who will share their accumulated wisdom from years of paddle boarding. They'll outfit you with a personal flotation device (PFD), paddle board and paddling equipment, giving you insight on the best ways to set up your board. You'll receive instruction on a variety of paddling strokes and have the opportunity to practice each stroke by the shore.

After you feel comfortable on the water, you'll set out in a guided, interpretive tour with your group. You'll experience the freedom of skimming across the water, learning about the ecosystem and history of the area.

All necessary paddleboarding equipment is provided.

Prerequisite: None

Activity level: Easy

Minimum age: 8 (14 and under with parent or guardian)

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending.  Go to www.llbean.com/dedham to sign up!

results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary.


• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal here: "Boston 1 - Join us"

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: "Boston 1 e-waiver"


• Make sure to check our Facebook, </a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.


• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.


• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 


All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Who doesn't wish they were more wise?

But we sometimes--maybe too often!--depend on our own experience, learning from our own mistakes and failures, when we could learn from others who lived before us!  And what if we could not only benefit from the wisdom of others but from a divinely guided wisdom?

That's what the book of Proverbs is, a guide to living life well.  So whether you think you're a simple person who doesn't know anything or you think you're already wise, come listen to "Wisdom" as she "makes known her words" (Pr 1:23)!

results.description:
$8.00 entrance fee to Hopkinton State Park at this time.

It looks like where in for a HOT (90 degree day) so I suggest you bring plenty of water, soda, juice to drink along with few snacks (few extra to share might be nice) for energy to play some of the outdoor yards games.  Also might want to bring suntan lotion and insect repellant.

There will be NO COOKOUT this TIME, but dinner afterwards to those that are interested.  The last time we went to Carbone's Restaurant, just around the corner and the time before we went to Bill's Pizza in downtown Hopkinton. Either is ok by me or bring your suggestion and we can take a vote!

Some members plan to stay close to the beach area and not hike.  Some are still up for a hike so we can do both.  Why not?  I'll try to set up all the games as close to the beach as possible and maybe will have enough wind to fly some kites?  I'm bringing a couple new ones. 

Please if you’re not going to attend take a couple of minutes to RSVP.

Let's put those sneakers on again and hike another section of Hopkinton State Park and for those who want to be a kid again bring your kite and outdoor yard games.

Outdoor yards games and hike may be happening at the same time. So do whatever you prefer or both. Volunteers needed to lead the hikes.

Planning on going to dinner after 5PM for those who are interested.  Just send me a text message with YES - I'm going to dinner afterwards.

  PLEASE READ ALL OF THE INFORMATION BELOW.

As you enter the park, turn LEFT and follow the route towards the MAIN BEACH AREA. There is very large parking lot at the Main Beach Area and several others close by.  See the map below with all the details.

If you have signed up to join us and your plans change, please UPDATE your RSVP. PLEASE DON'T BE A NO SHOW! 

It only takes a few minutes to change your RSVP to NO and to send a quick message.

 See the map below for the exact meet-up location.

For the online map - click the link below.

http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/hopkinton.pdf

Note: There is NO Alcohol allowed nor any littering at the State Park.

Public Bathrooms will be available on the premises.

Shown below are some of the outdoor yard games that I will be providing.

See the instructions and video of how to play the game. If the games are of interest please take the time to learn as much about the game as possible before you arrive.  It's been several years since I've played some of these games and I don't remember as much as I use too :-)!

Have you ever play Kubb?

Kubb is a lawn game where the object is to knock over wooden blocks by throwing wooden sticks at them. Kubb can be simply described as a combination of bowling and horseshoes. The ultimate object of the game is to knock the "king" over, before the opponent does.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=liMZ-dFMJSc

How about Cornhole?

Scoring is simple. After all bags have been thrown, a bag remaining on the board is worth 1 point. A bag that went in the hole is worth 3 points. Add up how many points you earned and compare them to your opponents. Equal points cancel each other out so that only one team can score per round. For example, if you scored 5 points and your opponent scored 3, you will add 2 points to your overall score and your team will throw first in the next round. If you scored 6 points and your opponent scored 6 as well, there will be no points awarded and whoever threw first in the last round will throw first again. A game is won when a team reaches 21 points with a lead of 2 or more points. The first team to win 2 games wins the match.

Ladder Game

Ladder Game, space the game ladders about 15 feet apart and start tossing your bolas. Each player tosses all 3 bolas, then the next player tosses all 3 bolas. The first one to 21 without going over is the winner! The top rung is worth 3 points, middle is 2 and bottom rung is 1 point.

Horsehoes

Horsehoes, there are two ways to score: by throwing "ringers" or by throwing the horseshoe nearest to the stake. A ringer is a thrown horseshoe such that the horseshoe completely encircles the stake. Disputes are settled by using a straightedge to touch the two points at the ends of the horseshoe, called "heel calks". If the straightedgedoesn't touch the stake, then the horseshoe is a ringer.

Kickball - Let's act like kids again and have some fun playing this game!  

Have any questions?  Just give me a call, send a message or email: [masked]  I don't want to post my cell phone number on this site, but will email to you. 

Rain cancels this event!!

Organizer assumes no liability either before, during, or after this event.
results.name: FWF (Fun With Friends) Hopkinton State Park Multi-Group Event

results.description:
Delete Delete Delete. Ok so now that you have taken thousands of photos, time to decide which to keep and which to delete. Part of becoming a better photographer is learning how to SEE the difference in photos that are good and those that are great. In this first session we will focus on images from nature.

 Join us to discover a simple step by step system for critiquing your photos and taking them from like to love.

About your instructor: Suzanne Merritt  is a master level photography instructor with a studio at the Boston Center for the Arts. She has been leading workshops on the topics of creativity, photography and beauty in Asia, Europe and the US for over 20 years. Suzanne was the founder of the Polaroid Creativity Lab and has recently launched the Curious Soul Photo School. She has a masters degree in Aesthetic Education. You can see her photography and subscribe to her blog at: www.curioussoulphotos.com


I loved this one immediately. A keeper for sure.

Why do we like some photos and LOVE others?  Some just have that special ELUSIVE quality that is difficult to put into words but we know it when we see it. We feel an immediate connection to the image and sense it is good one. We immediately put a heart or star next to those since it is love at first sight.

On the other hand, most of us are also pretty good at detecting the images that are not good at all and never will be no matter what edits we do.  We can hit delete with with out hesitation.

Which boat image is stronger  A or B? Not sure? Do you see the difference? 

The  majority of our images may be in the middle range, not great and not terrible,  where we are really not sure. Are they good? Could the be better? Should I keep or delete? You can quickly accumulate thousands of images in this mid range and never get back to them. We have good intensions but are just too busy to deal with these. They quickly get out of hand and before you know it you have thousands of maybe someday photos. 

There are some powerful clear guidelines or criteria you can apply to your own work to make it stronger. I have been using these for years in my own work and now am happy to share them with you. I have a masters degree in Aesthetic Education, the science of beauty in nature and art, and can offer you some specific critiquing and judging skills you can use from this point on.  This will help you break the photo hoarding habit and delete delete delete. 

This is not so much about how to do the edits, but about what edits to do and why. This is not a class on using Lightroom. It is a workshop to cultivate your critical eye so you can more quickly judge your photos and decide what edits to do. 

Which Flower Photo is stronger A. or B.?

Some of the topics covered in this workshop:

• Three essential questions to ask yourself to decide whether to keep or delete.

• Four simple steps you can take to gently edit your best photos to make them even better.

• How to see the difference that makes the difference when comparing two photos of the same subject. A or B which is better and why.

Which twig do you keep?

This is not a technical class on editing your photos. There are plenty of other classes out there on the use of Photoshop, Lightroom, or other editing software. We will focus on the CREATIVE SEEING PROCESS of judging your images to see and emphasize their strengths and edit out the visual distractions. Think of it as developing the “good eye” so you can spot the keepers. 

Taking time to learn how to judge and gently edit your images during this day will also help you take better pictures in the future. Once you know what to look for, you can make these same choices while taking photos by editing your experience in the moment. This will save you time and effort in the future because then your photos will need very little editing. 

Which would you delete?


This class will also build your confidence in your aesthetic judgment in sensing which images have that elusive quality that makes them shine. You know it when you see it, even if you can’t quite name it. Learning to recognize this quality takes time, but in this class you will begin to learn how to move in that direction. We each have an inner guiding compass, a nose for the truth that guides us toward the images we long to take, the ones that capture the beauty of life and express something that will only be expressed through us. 


Which shadow evokes a mood?

How we will work:

• I will start with an inspiring slide show of sample photos that went from good to GREAT with simple edits and provide the criteria. Once you see these clear examples, you can apply the same principles to your own work. I will explain harmony, balance, dynamic  tension and other aesthetic qualities. 

• You will look at your images and practice applying the criteria so you can sense the difference between what you like and what you love.

• You will work with a partner to objectively look at the work of others and how to get and give constructive feedback.

• I will show a slide show of simple edits you can easily make using iPhoto on a Mac computer. Even as you gently edit your images by cropping, lightening, or adding more contrast, you need to know how to judge how much, where, what, etc. 

• You will choose several of your own images from nature to apply the edits I demonstrate. THIS IS A HANDS ON WORKSHOP. 

As always, we will have a social time at the end of class so you can join us for a quick glass of wine, a beer and snacks at the Bee Hive if you like. 

Special note: This workshop is designed for Mac users. I am going to be demonstrating the editing tools on iPhoto. Please bring your laptop so you can work on your images during the class. This class will be limited to 8 participants so if you would like to attend, please RSVP right away. 

Many of you have asked for this class so I am very excited to be offering it now. I look forward to seeing you this Saturday. If you are a PC user and really want to attend, contact me and I will see what we can do to include you. If you know how to use basic editing software you will be able to attend.

Suzanne

Founder Curioussoulphotos.com

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4

results.description:
The original Wharf is back !    

Victor Molle's family has owned and operated the Marina at the Wharf since 1977. He started  on the bar and has done every job in the restaurant and in North Shore Marine (the marina) since then and will do any job now. You can always find family here when he is not , which is not very often.

We have many different menu choices including seafood, steak, chicken, veal, pasta, burgers, and pizza. There is something for everyone. We have entertainment on the weekends and offer a full bar. 

Join us for Sunday Brunch. We have over 30 delicious items, including a carving station and omlette station on our Brunch!  Sunday Brunch is from 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM every week.  

For those of you who do not know......... Our restaurant opened in 1977 as a small restaurant of approximately forty seats on the Pines River in Revere. As the years went on we became more popular and in order to accommodate our guests, we opened the current dining room, known to many as the Big Room, in 1987.

In 2004, we leased out our restaurant and retired from the restaurant business until October, 2013.  It was then that we came out of retirement  and "The Wharf" was back!

We have changed our name to the Marina at the Wharf, but yes, we are the well known and loved Wharf.


http://www.marinaatthewharf.com/lunch

results.description:
Fort Revere is a classic location for location portrait photography. It presents many options for classic and grunge style portraiture.  There is phenomenal graffiti and the run down buildings have that abandoned feeling that gives the images an air of mystery.  Whether you are shooting indoors or out this place is a favorite of local portrait photographers and a regular haunt for location shoots of seniors.

Join Ian  and a professional model as he takes you through shooting setups and lighting arrangements for getting the best out of this location.  Included is a rare opportunity to learn the techniques of grunge style senior photography which is one of the most sought after and profitable portraiture styles.

We will cover:

Lighting for outdoor shooting

Use of reflectors

Posing techniques

using stairs

using windows

using doorways

Indoor low light portraits

Natural light portraiture

Grunge portraiture

Lighting for indoor portraiture

We will begin at 3pm and end around 6pm .   This class is planned for later in the day to make best use of the light in this location.

Cost for the 3 hour workshop is just $75.  In order for this class to take place a minimum of four participants is required.  The total number of participants for this workshop is limited to just 8 so  that everyone will get ample time to shoot.

Reflectors, stands, strobes, and remote triggers will be available.

For more details contact Ian at [masked]
results.name: On Location Lighting  Workshop - Fort Revere Hull

How can you receive healing or guidance from the natural world?  How might you build a relationship with a place, plant, animal or rock?  What could you offer back as a creative response?

We'll begin indoors, later heading out together, most likely carpooling to the Acton Arboretum (depending on weather.)  Join us for the whole thing, or just the first part at the church, if you prefer.  We'll probably end by 6pm at the latest.   Our actual ending time is negotiable, depending on weather and what participants want.

Stay tuned for further details.

results.description:
Enjoy Pizza? Mystery? Murder? Only someone who should walk the plank would answer no to one of those!

What is a "Murder Mystery Party"?

In essence, each attendee is assigned a character that knows certain information related to the plot. You then socialize as that character to find out what others know and just enjoy the company there. Think of this as a party with a plot. For a further example, you can see the murder mystery party that was held last year: http://www.meetup.com/BostonJapaneseAnimeFilmSocialGroup/events/223430910/ (held at this same location).

What is the plot of this party?

Murder Among the Mateys: https://www.nightofmystery.com/shop/murder-among-the-mateys--19

I like the idea but don't have a costume...

A costume is encouraged but not required for this event. Seriously don't sweat the costume or feel like you will be viewed negatively for not putting effort into it.

I have anime cosplay. Can I wear that?

YES! We are the anime group, after all. ;) If you know what you might want to wear, please let us know so that we can try to assign a story character that might fit.

What is the cost?

There is no cost currently. However, this is a potluck. We will need people to bring food and drinks (including alcohol). Please post what you intend to bring and let us know if you have questions on what might be good.

RSVP Restrictions 

* Be 18+ in age. 


(NOTE: Of course, those under 21 cannot drink. Don't worry though! I will be joining those who can't or don't drink. It isn't needed to have fun nor is it the focus of this event).


Stuff happening beyond the murder mystery?

There will be some socializing. And, as we are an anime club, there may be some light anime watching involved. :)

Directions / Transportation

Location: My apartment is above a business known as "The Lower Depths". There have been several events held here at the past and this is essentially a farewell event to the place since I'm moving out on Sunday.

Parking: There is street parking that is free after 6:00 PM so you may need quarters to feed the meter for two hours if you are driving. Beyond parking on Commonwealth Ave, there are a few meters hiding behind my building located near: goo.gl/yqrXDi. 

I have other questions you didn't cover!

Post them in the comments below and we will be glad to provide you with a response. :)

results.description:
We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are very few RSVPs.

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or Chinatown on the Orange Line.
Also a short walk from Park Street or Downtown Crossing. 

• From Boylston Station, go south on Tremont Street (away from Boston Common),  then take a right onto Stuart Street.  The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

• From Chinatown Station, go west on Boylston Street (toward Boston Common), then take a left onto Tremont Street. Turn right onto Stuart Street. The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

There is a map of the area below. If you have trouble finding us, please feel free to call or text me at[masked]-2923.  Also you can call or text if you come after we have left for Chinatown, although then there is a greater chance I will miss the call.

Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

The Meetup does not end at 6 - instead, some time around there, we usually go out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards to eat family style - anyone who wants to come is welcome. The cost is usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks for which people pay their own way).  We are open to restaurant suggestions.  However, I am not willing to get into dividing up large numbers of orders on one giant check, which is why we generally go to Chinatown and split everything down the middle.  If you don't want to eat at all, you can come and just enjoy the company for free.  

Please BRING CASH if you can and want to go to dinner - many of the restaurants limit cards to two per table, so if a lot of people have no cash it can be a problem.

Stuart Street view

results.description:
This is almost in Revere, so easy in n' out. Never Cirque'd before, but I had been amazed watching them on video. Extremely talented artists. 

What if, by engaging your imagination and opening your mind, you could alter reality and unlock the door to a world of wonders? Welcome to the realm of KURIOS -- Cabinet of Curiosities from Cirque du Soleil. Step into the curio cabinet of an ambitious inventor who defies the laws of time, space and dimension in order to reinvent everything around him. Suddenly, the visible becomes invisible, perspectives are transformed, and the world is literally turned upside down in a place that's as beautiful as it is mysterious. Stunning acrobatics blend with unusual curiosity acts, and otherworldly characters spring to life before your eyes. Is this magical, mechanical land real, or just a figment of your imagination? You have to see it to disbelieve it. The magic is happening this summer in the Grand Chapiteau at Suffolk Downs in Boston. Get your tickets now before they go on sale to the general public.


https://www.goldstar.com/events/boston-ma/cirque-du-soleils-kurios-cabinet-of-curiosities-tickets
results.how_to_find_us: Tix $35 n' Up
results.name: Cirque du Soleil's KURIOS -  Suffolk Downs -   Boston

results.description:
In this highly imaginative, delightfully absurdist comedy from visionary filmmaker Yorgos Lanthimos (Oscar-nominee Dogtooth), Colin Farrell stars as David, a man who has just been dumped by his wife. To make matters worse, David lives in a society where single people have 45 days to find true love, or else they are turned into the animal of their choice and released into the woods. David is kept at the mysterious HOTEL while he searches for a new partner, and after several romantic misadventures decides to make a daring escape to abandon this world. He ultimately joins up with a rebel faction known as The Loners, a group founded on a complete rejection of romance. But once there David meets an enigmatic stranger (Rachel Weisz) who stirs up unexpected and strong feelings within him…. At once a full immersion into a strange and surreal world, and a witty and clever reflection of our own society, The Lobster is a thrillingly audacious vision fully brought to life by Lanthimos and his terrific cast, the perfect balance between sharp-edged satire and romantic fable. (Kendall theater blurb)

From Anthony Lane’s review in The New Yorker: “...No art, for a filmmaker as for a novelist, is finer or harder than that of keeping a straight face as you hold the world up to scorn. Swift managed it, and so did Buñuel, but few current directors, apart from Lanthimos and Todd Solondz, make the effort. . . . The Lobster is more than a satire on the dating game. It digs deeper, needling at the status of our most tender emotions.”

91% "fresh" critics score at Rotten Tomatoes. This films seems sure to generate a great discussion afterwards!

It's a Saturday evening, so you may want to buy your ticket in advance.


I will wait in the lobby near the ticket-takers until 4:30. If you miss sitting with the group, we will gather after the film in the same place, the lobby near the ticket-takers. From there we’ll venture out for a meal, drink, and discussion. I, for one, will probably avoid seafood after seeing this film.
results.how_to_find_us: I will wait in the lobby near the ticket-takers until 4:30. If you miss sitting with the group, we will gather after the film in the same place.

Hi everyone! 

Thanks for a lively discussion in our April 23rd bible study, I think we had about 20 people participate.  

The group decided the next topic would be "Blooming Where You're Planted", or how to be effective in your church and other roles as a single Christian.  Sometimes churches do not have  opportunities structured for single Christians for fellowship and spiritual growth as they might have for families or children.  

How can we best serve and interact with the rest of the church?  What opportunities are there for single Christians to impact their church, and relationships with family, friends, co-workers, etc?

We look forward to hearing your thoughts and questions in this study and turning to the Bible for guidance!  

You're always welcome to come to any Bible Studies that fit your schedule. The studies will be structured as independent sessions, so you won't be lost if you miss one!

There will be someone who can watch children if you have that need.

We hope you can join us!

results.description:
Darkest Dungeon $24.99 [PC]

Darkest Dungeon is a challenging gothic roguelike turn-based RPG about the psychological stresses of adventuring. Recruit, train, and lead a team of flawed heroes against unimaginable horrors, stress, famine, disease, and the ever-encroaching dark. Can you keep your heroes together when all hope is lost?

Enter the Gungeon $14.99 [PC+PS4]

Enter the Gungeon is a bullet hell dungeon crawler following a band of misfits seeking to shoot, loot, dodge roll and table-flip their way to personal absolution by reaching the legendary Gungeon’s ultimate treasure: the gun that can kill the past.
 


Risk of Rain $9.99 [PC+PS4]

Risk of Rain is an action platformer with roguelike elements. With permanent death as a primary feature, players will have to play their best to get as far as possible. Fight on a mysterious planet with randomly spawning enemies and bosses, either alone or with 3 friends in online co-op.

Women’s instincts adaptive in the tribe to put kids first and pressure the man to always do better on food, smells that draw predators, security, and family status have turned deadly, discouraging men from the long, hard effort needed to understand basic causes, convince others to believe, and make drastic changes we need:

Women - Come casual but classy; do not have to come in a dress but blouses recommended over shirts.

results.description:
This event is free. If you would like a sword info is below. R.s.v.p's are not limited so bring friends along. The event will be heald in Boston Common Parade near Parkman Bandstand. Park St station is the closest train stop. Red, Green, and up the st from the Orange line.

To make it easier we will meet at Beantown pub at 7pm and cross the street around 7:30pm. Event starts at 8pm.

Live your Jedi dreams at an enormous light sword battle in the Boston area this springThe Light Battle Tour is coming to town on May 28, 2016.

True Star Wars fans have been practicing their light saber moves since the first time they experienced the legendary film. This May, Boston’s aspiring Jedis will have the opportunity to put those moves to use.

On May 28, the Light Battle Tour is coming to Boston and will give fans a chance to participate in what could be the largest local “light sword” battle to date. Participants will be split into two teams: the Space Warlocks, using red swords, and the Space Wizards, using every other color sword.
Reserve your light sword here: http://www.thelightbattle.com/collections/boston

No need to select your allegiance in advance: these swords can cycle through 6 colors red, blue, green, purple, orange, cyan, violet, or color-shift with the push of a button. They are 3' long and extend to 36" when fully extended, and are powered by 3 replaceable AG-13 batteries (included ). You will pick up your sword(s) in person at the event.

After all the swords have been distributed, we will gather, split into sides, and the battle will begin! The event is being produced by Newmindspace.

https://vimeo.com/152659158

The event is free for anyone who wants to bring their own equipment. For those in need of a light sword, they are currently on sale on the company’s website for an early bird price of $5, of which $1 will go to Make-A-Wish Foundation. Participants who reserve swords can keep them once the battle is done.

A note about e-mail addresses: Please use your primary e-mail address when you place your order - you may want your confirmation later on.

Refund FAQ:﻿

Q: If I don't show up to claim my sword, can I get a refund afterward?

A: No. There are a limited amount, and if you reserve one, that means somebody else will not get one. All light swords are final sale! You can, however, transfer your confirmation to somebody else.
results.name: Light Sword Battle Boston (FREE)

results.description:
In Bordeaux wine, the whole of its parts is the result of blending different varietals to capture each one’s unique qualities that create overall knockout combinations.  France’s AOC (appellation d'origine controlee) allows only the following varietals to be in a Bordeaux red: Cabernet Franc, Cabernet Sauvignon, Carmenére, Malbec, Merlot, and Petit Verdot.

The Meritage (rhymes with heritage) brand name came into being in 1988 when a group of American vinters formed the Meritage Association to identify and label high quality Bordeaux style blends.  Since wineries outside of Bordeaux that make Bordeaux style wines cannot call their wines Bordeaux, the Meritage name was a way to highlight their own wines made in the same style.  To be clear, there are also many wineries that make Bordeaux style blends that choose not to put the brand name Meritage on their bottles; these are not official Meritage wines.

Due to space, this tasting will be a ten-person tasting.  Once we have all the wines, we will mix the bottles up and, in addition to the typical rating, we will try to guess if a wine is Meritage or Bordeaux.  It is important that we have exactly five bottles of each so that the odds are fair for the wines!   Please bring a good quality wine since there are only ten to try.  This will be a free wine tasting.  When you RSVP, you will be put on a waitlist.  In order to move on to the RSVP list, you must put down a $20 deposit in advance via Paypal; I will send my Paypal information to those on the waitlist in the order received, and upon payment, your RSVP will be confirmed.  At the night of the tasting, we will refund you $20 when you show up.  There will be no refunds for cancellations and no shows.  The only way to get a refund is to show up at the tasting.  Please only RSVP if you know you will be attending.

For the tasting, please bring the following:

•  1 bottle of Bordeaux/Meritage red wine in the $20 - $40 range in a paper bag (we will assign individuals which to bring)

•  1 food item to share  (here are some ideas for pairing Meritage and Bordeaux:  cheese like goat cheese, comte, manchego, or roquefort, meats like broiled or grilled lamb/beef, duck/goose pate, and dark chocolate.  These are all very heavy so veggies are also welcome!)  Please post the item you are bringing once your RSVP is confirmed so that there are no repeats.

•  4 wine glasses

For those coming from afar, there are two visitor's parking permits.  Other parking can be found up the street (meters til 8pm).  The house is about a 15 minute walk from Davis Square or a 5 minute walk from the bus stop.  And you can always Uber!
results.name: Bordeaux vs. Meritage

results.description:
After 15 years of performing together and recording on each other’s solo CDs, Portland, ME based flute player Nicole Rabata and Boston based fiddler Ellery Klein decided a group together was long overdue. With the addition of Bethany Waickman on guitar, the trio found a sound rooted in the traditional Irish music Ellery and Nicole honed during years abroad in the Irish cities of Cork, Limerick, and Ennis ... as well as the depths of Nicole’s virtuosic classical music career, Ellery’s Americana sounds and Bethany’s soft-spoken, yet driving, guitar playing. Fódhla have been well received at festivals such as Portland’s Saltwater Fest, the Maine Celtic Celebration and Boston’s BCMFest. Their debut recording “Notes from Mill Pond” was released in December 2015 to a sold-out show at Acoustic Artisans in Portland, ME.

Irish fiddler Ellery Klein brings a style steeped in traditional Irish sounds and seasoned with American fiddle styles. She toured with Billboard-charting Irish music group Gaelic Storm from[masked] and was a founding member of Irish all-female ensemble Long Time Courting. In 2015, she was invited to be a featured soloist with Duluth, MN’s Lake Superior Chamber Orchestra, performing Nickitas Demos’Double Concerto for Celtic and Bluegrass Fiddler. She holds an MA in Traditional Irish Music from the University of Limerick.


Irish flutist Nicole Rabata is highly regarded both in and out of traditional music fields. She has toured America and Europe. In 2014, she spent two months in India where she performed and taught music at the Gandhi Ashram School in the Himalayas. She spent four years in the west of Ireland where she immersed herself in the music and was influenced by the playing of many great musicians. Her playing is featured on the feature film 'The Heavenly Angle' along with Natalie MacMaster. She is on the faculty at Colby College and 317 Main St. Community Music Center in Maine.

Guitarist Bethany Waickman grew up in musical family in upstate, NY and started playing the piano at an early age. One of her earliest experiences with traditional music was attending Meadowlark music camp with her family. It was there that she was inspired to take up the guitar. Bethany formed the contra dance trio, Anadama, with Amelia Mason and Emily Troll while working at Pinewoods in 2007, and they have gone on to delight dancers throughout the northeast. Bethany started performing with The Lissa Schneckenburger Band in Dec. of 2008, and can be seen with Lissa on tours throughout the US, Canada and Europe.

ABOUT THE CAFE
You can arrive as early as 6pm to enjoy the cafe's offerings, which include sandwiches/wraps, salads, coffee, teas and pastries as well as beer and wine.
Free parking in the back lot, on street (mind the signage) and two satellite lots.
MBTA: Arts at the Armory is approximately a 15 minute walk from Davis Square which is on the MBTA Red Line, or take either the 88 or 90 bus from Lechmere (Green Line) or Davis Square (Red Line). Get off at the Highland Avenue and Lowell Street stop. You can also get there from Sullivan Square (Orange Line) via the 90 bus. Get off at the Highland Avenue and Benton Road stop.
Bicycle: The Armory is four blocks from the Somerville Community Path.
Handicap accessible.

ABOUT NOTLOB MUSIC
Since 2007, notloB Music has presented close to 200 folk, old-time, bluegrass, progressive string band, world and Celtic concerts in unique venues throughout the greater Boston area.
mail list - http://tinyurl.com/notlobmail
website - https://sites.google.com/site/notlobmusic/
facebook - https://www.facebook.com/notloBParlourConcerts/
eventbrite(tickets) - http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315

results.description:
Cape Breton musicians Wendy MacIsaac & Andrea Beaton bring their lively traditional tunes to the Canadian American Club for a Downeast style dance. Come learn the straightforward Mabou square set or simply sit and enjoy the music in the authentic atmosphere of the Canadian American Club. It's such a treat to have both of these remarkable representatives of the Cape Breton style!

Wendy MacIsaac is a renowned fiddler from Cape Breton who has been playing music for over 30 years. She is recognized as one of the "old school" style of players who has kept the traditional sound going and has a deep respect for it. She is highly sought after not only to teach the genre, but also to play at dances all over Nova Scotia where her style energizes the dancers. Wendy is also an accomplished pianist and step dancer. Her latest recording, Off the Floor, won ECMA Traditional Instrumental Recording of the Year. Her prior album, Seinn, recorded with Gaelic singer Mary Jane Lamond, was awarded Canadian Folk Music Award Winner Traditional Album of the Year in 2013.

Andrea Beaton comes from a long line of musicians, composers and dancers. She is an award-winning fiddler, tune composer and recording artist who is known for her powerful bow and driving style. She tours and teaches internationally and is in great demand as a teacher at music camps and fiddling/dancing workshops. She has released 5 solo albums, one duo album with her father, Kinnon Beaton, and a book of her original tunes. she also recorded an album with her family "The Beaton family of Mabou" in 2007 for the Smithsonian Institute. Most of her solo albums were nominated for awards, and her 2010 CD, 'Branches,' won the Canadian East Coast Music Awards "Instrumental Recording of the Year!" Andrea travels the globe, sharing her culture as well as exploring and writing contemporary tunes. Her music, dance and comical stories are sure to delight any audience.
Tickets are $15 and available in advance at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2538122
or at the door the day of the show.
results.name: Cape Breton Dance/Concert with Andrea Beaton & Wendy MacIsaac

results.description:
Cape Breton musicians Wendy MacIsaac & Andrea Beaton bring their lively traditional tunes to the Canadian American Club for a Downeast style dance. Come learn the straightforward Mabou square set or simply sit and enjoy the music in the authentic atmosphere of the Canadian American Club. It's such a treat to have both of these remarkable representatives of the Cape Breton style!

Wendy MacIsaac is a renowned fiddler from Cape Breton who has been playing music for over 30 years. She is recognized as one of the "old school" style of players who has kept the traditional sound going and has a deep respect for it. She is highly sought after not only to teach the genre, but also to play at dances all over Nova Scotia where her style energizes the dancers.

Wendy is also an accomplished pianist and step dancer.

Her latest recording, Off the Floor, won ECMA Traditional Instrumental Recording of the Year. Her prior album, Seinn, recorded with Gaelic singer Mary Jane Lamond, was awarded Canadian Folk Music Award Winner Traditional Album of the Year in 2013.

Andrea Beaton comes from a long line of musicians, composers and dancers. She is an award-winning fiddler, tune composer and recording artist who is known for her powerful bow and driving style. She tours and teaches internationally and is in great demand as a teacher at music camps and fiddling/dancing workshops.

She has released 5 solo albums, one duo album with her father, Kinnon Beaton, and a book of her original tunes. she also recorded an album with her family "The Beaton family of Mabou" in 2007 for the Smithsonian Institute. Most of her solo albums were nominated for awards, and
her 2010 CD, 'Branches,' won the Canadian East Coast Music Awards "Instrumental Recording of the Year!"

Andrea travels the globe, sharing her culture as well as exploring and writing contemporary tunes. Her music, dance and comical stories are sure to delight any audience.
Tickets are $15 and available in advance at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2538122
or at the door the day of the show.

If you can't get enough of Andrea and Wendy, they will be joined by Eric MacDonald for a mid-week concert on June 1, 7:30 pm at Arlington Center for the Arts!  Tickets: eventbrite (tickets - http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315
results.name: Andrea Beaton & Wendy MacIsaac perform for a Dance/Concert

results.description:
By signing up and/or attending a Boston Area Photography Group meetup you agree to the Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer below.

No guests are permitted on Boston Area Photography Group events. Please have your guests join our Meetup. 

MEETUP DESCRIPTION:  

OUR TEASER: https://vimeo.com/152659158 

RESERVE YOUR LIGHT SWORD: http://www.thelightbattle.com/collections/boston 

A Fan-Run, Charitable Event to Benefit Make-A-Wish Massachusetts & Rhode Island 

Join us for a massive battle of space wizards vs. space warlocks in Boston. Pick a side and use that venerable, ancient, glowing tool: the light sword, in the ultimate nocturnal showdown. In December we broke the world record - this should be epic. 

For every $5 (early bird - $10 normally) you contribute, we will reserve one light sword for you. Each light sword changes up to 6 colors is about 3' long, and you will be able to pick them up at the event. 

We will start to gather at 8:00, split into space warlocks (red swords) vs. space wizards (everyone else) a little after 9:00, and the battle will begin. The fun awakens! 


I drove by there this morning and things are starting to pop. Next weekend should be amazing. Of course that also means amazing crowds so I suggest we get there when it opens. Unfortunately that isn't until 8:00 am but that's probably still early enough to feel like we own the place once we get back into the grounds. As many of you know this is also a world renowned birding location so bring that long glass if you've a mind to.

GEAR/CLOTHING/FOOTWARE SUGGESTIONS: Anything good in low light and fast focusing as tripods won't be an option

Remember: we are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment.

Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: 
By using this site, you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's owners, principals, affiliates, presenters, organizer, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in part out of the activities, advice or information contained herein. You further agree that if you or someone under your supervision uses the information on this website you assume all risks of injury, damage, and economic loss, without limitation, and release providers from all liability therefore.

results.description:
This is the 12th Annual Boston's Run to Remember.  It's a memorial run to honor First Responders who have died in the line of duty.  You can register for the event, and you can also elect to fund raise for the charity.  

Race information:


Distances:  5 miles or 13.1 miles.  Both of these races start at the same time and travel along the same route and split after about 2 or 3 miles.  There is a minimum time/speed needed to participate in the 13.1 mile race.  If you don't reach the 2 mile mark in 28 minutes, you'll be diverted to the 5 mile race.  This is also nice, since if you aren't feeling like you can make 13 miles, you can run the shorter course

Training:  If you're attempting the half, and you aren't much of a runner, you should start your training now.  Most training programs are 12 weeks, but I'd suggest adding some weeks in case you get sick or injured.  Here are a couple of programs: http://www.halhigdon.com/training/51130/Half-Marathon-Training-Guide  If folks are interested, and our schedules align, we might be able to do some training together (maybe 1x week).   A 5-mile (or 8K) training plan is available here:  http://www.halhigdon.com/training/51095/8K-Training-Guide

Registration and more info is available at: http://www.bostonsruntoremember.com/boston/index.html


Inspirational quote:  "A moment of pain is worth a lifetime of glory."  - Louis Zamperini
results.how_to_find_us: We will figure this out as we get closer to the event

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots, sneakers are not recommended.  We do encounter streams, wet leaves and rocks, from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 


Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking, Rolling terrrain

results.description:
Newburyport to Exeter
Sunday - May 29

Ride Type: Cue Sheet, Arrowed, GPS

Times and Routes: 9:30 AM for 25, 47 and 64 miles

Leaders: Pierre Avignon [masked]), Eli Post [masked])

Description: From beautiful Newburyport, we'll wind through some lovely back roads into Southern New Hampshire. Both rides will follow stretches of quiet roads along the Merrimack River with the longer ride heading as far north as Exeter, where you can stop for lunch. ! Terrain: Mostly gentle rolling, no real challenging hills.

Start: Nock Middle School, 70 Low Street, Newburyport, MA 01950

Directions: Rte 95 North (from split off of Rte 128 in Peabody) to Exit 57. Keep right at the ramp towards Newburyport then turn right at the second set of lights into Low Street. NPT Middle School is ~1 mile on your left after a set of lights. Plan to arrive by 09:00 AM, park as close to Low Street as possible to reserve parking spaces for any activity at the skate park

More information and UPDATES: http://crw.org/rides/ride.php?id=27&year=2016

results.description:
Registration on the L.L. Bean website is required to attend this event. Visit www.llbean.com/dedham to reserve your spot.


90 minute classes begin at varied times both Saturday and Sunday.

Description:

Our Kayaking Discovery Course is a great way to learn the basic paddling techniques and safety skills of this popular sport. Exploring nature in a kayak is a healthy and fun way to enjoy the outdoors. Our course begins with a brief introduction and safety talk from our friendly paddling instructors, who will share their knowledge gained from years of kayaking. They'll outfit you with a personal flotation device (PFD), kayak and paddling equipment, giving you insight on the best ways to set up your boat. Then, you'll receive instruction on a variety of paddling techniques.

After you feel comfortable on the water, you'll set out in a kayak on a guided, interpretive tour with your group. You'll experience the freedom of skimming across the water, learning about the ecosystem and history of the area.

All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

Prerequisite: None

Activity level: Easy

Minimum age: 8 (14 and under with parent or guardian)

90 minute classes begin at varied times both Saturday and Sunday.

Description:

Discover how easy it is to balance on top of the water. Our paddle boarding starter course is an excellent opportunity to learn the basic strokes and skills you'll need for maneuvering a paddle board, allowing you to explore scenic lakes, coves and inlets.

Our course begins with a brief introduction and safety talk from our friendly paddling instructors, who will share their accumulated wisdom from years of paddle boarding. They'll outfit you with a personal flotation device (PFD), paddle board and paddling equipment, giving you insight on the best ways to set up your board. You'll receive instruction on a variety of paddling strokes and have the opportunity to practice each stroke by the shore.

After you feel comfortable on the water, you'll set out in a guided, interpretive tour with your group. You'll experience the freedom of skimming across the water, learning about the ecosystem and history of the area.

All necessary paddleboarding equipment is provided.

Prerequisite: None

Activity level: Easy

Minimum age: 8 (14 and under with parent or guardian)

Note:  This meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending.  Go to www.llbean.com/dedham to sign up!

results.description:
Hi Soccer Comrades!  

Why not come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 11:00 AM Sunday?  We will do this at the soccer field of Belmont High School, located to the left of the ice hockey rink and turf field (when viewed from the street).

Here are a few things to remember:

·  This is the "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.  That said, we highly encourage all players to wear shin guards to protect against accidental knobbling.

·  Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy. 

·  Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather

·  Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

You can find the location at Google Maps with the link: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.39523,-71.1674112,466m/data=!3m1!1e3

The soccer field is located just to the left of the Viglirolo Skating Rink, which is located to the left of turf field (when seen from the Concord Ave).

results.description:
The group has reached 700 members! Who knew there were so many like-minded corgi lovers in the area? As I was chatting with some of you at our last meetup, there aren't many parks left, that fit our criteria, for us to romp around. Cold Spring Park in Newton might just be our default go-to meetup spot, with the occasional beach/water romp at Stodder's Neck and Cat Rock. If you have any comments or recommendations, please post them to the group in the comments section for discussion.

As always, please be mindful of the weather to make for safe travels. If the weather turns for the worst, there will be no rain date and we'll just reschedule the following month.

Park Reminder: There is ample parking available. To get to the dog park, there is a 5-10 minute walk through a wooded path to get to the dog clearing.

Corgi Reminder: Don't forget to bring water for your pup and a towel for your car.

Have a park suggestion? Pass along any dog park suggestions for future consideration. Amenities that most owners appreciate are parking, fully-fenced, large grass field (since our group has gotten so big, we want to be respectful of the local dogs), no specific tags needed, and access to water.

results.description:
Every Sunday this month when you eat at Not Your Average Joe's in Watertown, 55 Main Street, 15% of your sale will go directly to the Association of Blind Citizens of Massachusetts to benefit the Boston Renegades.

This is the last Sunday to support your favorite Beep Baseball Team and have great food. Join Joe Quintanilla this Sunday. Joe Quintanilla was the first "Not Your average Joe" to join the Boston Renegades back in 2001. As a young kid, when asked in school what do you want to do when you grow up, he would answer "the left fielder for the Boston Red Sox like Jim Rice!" Retinitis Pigments got in the way of Joe's childhood dream, and he was never able to play little league.
In 2001 everything changed, Joe Q was one of the first players to join the Boston Renegades. "Hitting a ball that is pitched to you was and is an awesome experience!" He says. "I finally was able to play the outfield and wear number 14!" For sixteen years, Joe Q has been patrolling the outfield for the Renegades and leads the team in most games played and 2nd in runs scored.

Please print this flyer or show it on your phone to the hostess and server and 15% of your sales will benefit the Renegades.
results.name: Eat Well & Support Boston Renegades Beep Ball with special guest Joe Quintanilla

results.description:
Come and join us for open board gaming at Excelsior!  They have a large gaming area to seat approximately 50 gamers in addition to a growing board game library that patrons may take right off the library shelf and play at-will.  They have also dedicated their Sunday schedule for just this open board gaming event, so us board gamers will have the pick of the tables during the entirety of the event which happens to run the entire time the shop is open on Sundays.

Attendees are welcome to bring in their own games or use games from the library.  Bobby will also run game demos during the event in case you want to learn a new game or simply try before you buy.

In case you are interested in purchasing the game from the demo session, Excelsior will offer 10% off the price of purchasing a new copy of that game that day on top of the 10% discount they are offer to all MBG members (for a total discount of 20% off).  If for some reason they are out of stock of the demo game and must special order it for you that day, they will order it for you and allow you to take an additional 10% special order discount on top of the previous two discounts for a total discount of 30% off!

Want to special order something that is not the demo game?  Add the base TGA 10% discount and the 10% special order discount together for a total of 20% off any special orders.

Nourishment:  The shop carries various snacks and non-alcoholic beverages if you need something to snack or sip on while you game.  For more substantial food, there are many eateries located within walking distance from the shop on Main Street.

Parking:  Excelsior has an agreement in place with the Jiffy Lube at 3 Powder Mill Road.  Attendees may park in the lot behind the Jiffy Lube building.  From there, it is a short walk across Powder Mill Road to the Excelsior's door on the corner of Powder Mill and Waltham Street, which is the 4-way intersection closest to Jiffy Lube.
results.how_to_find_us: On the corner of Waltham Street and Powder Mill Road, park behind the Jiffy Lube
results.name: Sunday Board Gaming at Excelsior

results.description:
Since Grant was born last December, we've been very fortunate to be surrounded by long-time friends and meet so many new parent friends online and in person. This gathering is an opportunity for all of our circles to come together for a mega potluck picnic. This is a family-friendly event, you are encouraged to bring your kiddo(s) and partner(s). Dogs are welcome.

We live at Simmons College Residence Campus, where Jess Samuels is Director of Res Life and Robbie Samuels is a WAHD (work-at-home dad). We have a beautiful quad filled with lots of grass and Adirondack chairs. We have an indoor option if the weather doesn't cooperate, but plan for sun!

WHAT TO BRING:
A dish to share with serving utensils. Plan for 4 people and we'll have plenty for everyone. Non-alcoholic beverages, main dishes, side dishes, salads, appetizers, and desserts are all welcomed. No alcohol please.

**Please also bring a plate, utensils, and cup for each person in your party.**

If you are bringing children, please bring any toys or lawn games that they'd enjoy.

Allergens:
We want all of our friends to be able to enjoy themselves at this potluck picnic. To help make that possible for those with dietary restrictions/preferences: You will be asked to write down ingredients if your contribution is not store bought. We will also have colored dots for you to note whether your dish is vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free, and whether it contains peanuts or nuts.

Please let us know what you decide to bring by adding a comment in the event. Last minute decisions are also fine :-)

We look forward to seeing you!
Jess & Robbie

Getting here FAQs:
Simmons Residence Campus is in the Fenway near Longwood Medical area. Driving?
There are limited parking spots available on campus at 40 Pilgrim Road. There are non-meter parking spots nearby on Riverway.

Taking the T?
Fenway T stop is 8-10 minutes away. Here's walking directions from there: https://goo.gl/maps/RvTvW Want to walk less?
You could take the T to Kenmore and then take the 8/19/60/65 bus to "Pilgrim Road & Brookline Ave". There are a few bus options from Ruggles as well - and Central Square.

Whichever way you decide to travel, navigate to 40 Pilgrim Road. We will be setting up in front of Smith (building #8 on this map: http://www.simmons.edu/about-simmons/contact-us/campus-maps).
results.name: Family-friendly Potluck Picnic Memorial Day Weekend
